page.title: List of consorts of the Byzantine successor states

revision.text:
::''For the uncontested Empresses of the [[Eastern Roman Empire]], see, [[List of Roman and Byzantine Empresses]].'' ::''For the consorts of the Latin emperors, see, [[List of Latin Empresses]].'' This is a list of the [[Queen consort|consort]]s of the four main [[Byzantine Greeks|Byzantine Greek]] successor states of the [[Byzantine Empire]] following the [[Fourth Crusade]] in 1204 and up to their conquest by the [[Ottoman Empire]] in the middle of the 15th century. These states were [[Empire of Nicaea|Nicaea]], [[Empire of Trebizond|Trebizond]], [[Despotate of Epirus|Epirus]], and the [[Despotate of Morea|Morea]]. The last two never actually claimed the imperial title, except briefly under [[Theodore Komnenos Doukas]] in the late 1220s, who began as ruler of Epirus but crowned himself emperor in Thessalonica. == Empress of [[Empire of Nicaea|Nicaea]] == {| width=95% class="wikitable" | colspan="9" bgcolor=#66023C align=center| [[Laskarid dynasty|''''' Laskarid dynasty''''']] '''
(1204–1261)''' |- !Picture !Name !Father !Birth !Marriage !Became Empress !Ceased to be Empress !Death !Spouse |- |align="center"| |align="center"| [[Anna Angelina]] |align="center"| [[Alexios III Angelos|Alexios III]]

|align="center"| 18 August 1258 |align="center"| ? |align="center"| [[Theodore II Laskaris|Theodore II]] |- | colspan="9" bgcolor=gold align=center| [[Palaiologan dynasty|''''' Palaiologan dynasty''''']] '''
(1259–1261)''' |- |align="center"| [[File:Du Cange emperors.jpg|75px]] |align="center"| [[Theodora Palaiologina (Byzantine empress)|Theodora Palaiologina]] |align="center"| [[John Doukas Vatatzes]]
([[Vatatzes]]) |align="center"| c. 1240 |align="center"| 1253 |align="center"| 1 January 1259 ''as co-empress''
18 August 1258 ''as sole-empress consort'' |align="center"| 25 July 1261 |align="center"| 4 March 1303 |align="center"| [[Michael VIII]] |- !Picture !Name !Father !Birth !Marriage !Became Empress !Ceased to be Empress !Death !Spouse |} == Empress of [[Empire of Trebizond|Trebizond]] == The consorts of rulers of Trebizond, like their counterparts in the other two Byzantine successor states, the Empire of Nicaea and the Despotate of Epirus, initially claimed the traditional Byzantine title of ''Empress consort the Romans''. However, after reaching an agreement with the restored Byzantine Empire in 1282, the official title of the consorts of Trebizond was changed to ''Empress consort of the entire East, of the Iberians and the Perateia'' and remained such until the Empire's end in 1461. The state is sometimes called the Komnenian or Megalokomnenian empire from its ruling dynasty. Trebizond had three reigning empresses, [[Theodora of Trebizond]] (1284–1285), [[Irene Palaiologina of Trebizond|Irene Palaiologina]] (1340–1341), and [[Anna of Trebizond]] (1341–1342). {| width=95% class="wikitable" | colspan="9" bgcolor=#66023C align=center| [[Komnenid dynasty|'''''Megalokomnenid dynasty''''']] '''

([[Gattilusio]]) |align="center"| ? |align="center" colspan="2"| 27 July 1441 ''as Despoina in Morea'' |align="center" colspan="2"| July/August 1442 |- |align="center"| [[File:Palaiologos-Dynasty-Eagle.svg|75px]] |align="center"| [[Theodora Asanina]] |align="center"| Paul Asanes
(Asanes) |align="center"| ? |align="center"| before 1443 |align="center"| before 1443 ''as a Despoina in Morea''
29 May 1453 ''as Byzantine co-empress consort''It isn't known if she died before this date |align="center"| 1460 |align="center"| ? |align="center"| [[Demetrios Palaiologos]] |- |align="center"| [[File:Palaiologos-Dynasty-Eagle.svg|75px]] |align="center"| [[Catherine Zaccaria]] |align="center"| [[Centurione II Zaccaria]]
([[Zaccaria]]) |align="center"| around 1392 |align="center"| January 1430 |align="center"| before 1432 ''as a Despoina in Morea''
29 May 1453 ''as Byzantine co-empress consort'' |align="center"| 1460 |align="center"| 16 August 1462 |align="center"| [[Thomas Palaiologos]] |- !Picture !Name !Father !Birth !Marriage !Became Consort !Ceased to be Consort !Death !Spouse |} == Byzantine Empresses in [[pretext|pretence]] after 1453 == The [[Byzantine Empire]] fell in 1453. Three pretenders from the dynasty followed. The last Palaiologan pretender, [[Andreas Palaiologos]], sold his right to the imperial succession to [[Charles VIII of France]], but he also willed the imperial titles to [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]] and [[Isabella I of Castille]], and so in a sense either the [[List of French consorts|French]] [[List of Spanish consorts|Spanish queens]] have been the titular Empress of the Eastern Roman Empire since the 15th century. Another Palaiologan, [[Manuel Palaiologos]], sold his right of succession to [[Bayazid II|Ottoman Sultan Bayazid II]] (the Ottoman sultans already claim to be the Kaizer-i Rum or Roman Emperor); but since there is no such thing as a sultaness, there are no Ottoman consorts. Not counting the Ottoman, the two successors of the Palaiologans were all [[Catholic]] instead of [[Orthodox Church|Orthodox]]. {| width=95% class="wikitable" | colspan="9" bgcolor=66023C align=center| ''' Spouses of Byzantine Pretenders
(1453–1502)''' |- !Picture !Name !Father !Birth !Marriage !Became Empress !Ceased to be Empress !Death !Spouse |- |align="center"| [[File:Palaiologos-Dynasty-Eagle.svg|75px]] |align="center"| [[Theodora Asanina]] |align="center"| Paul Asanes
(Asanes) |align="center"| ? |align="center"| before 1443 |align="center"| 29 May 1453 ''as co-empress consort'' |align="center"| 1460 |align="center"| ? |align="center"| [[Demetrios Palaiologos]] |- |align="center"| [[File:Palaiologos-Dynasty-Eagle.svg|75px]] |align="center"| [[Catherine Zaccaria]] |align="center"| [[Centurione II Zaccaria]]
([[Zaccaria]]) |align="center"| around 1392 |align="center"| January 1430 |align="center"| before 1432 ''as a Despoina in Morea''
29 May 1453 ''as Byzantine co-empress consort'' |align="center" colspan="2"| 16 August 1462 |align="center"| [[Thomas Palaiologos]] |- |align="center" colspan="8"| A Roman prostitute ? |align="center"| [[Andreas Palaiologos]] |- |} == See also == * [[List of Holy Roman Empresses]] * [[List of Russian consorts]] * [[List of Latin empresses]] * [[List of Greek royal consorts]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Empresses of Nicaea| ]] [[Category:Empresses of Trebizond| ]] [[Category:Consorts of Epirus| ]] [[Category:Lists of queens|Byzantine, exiled]] [[Category:Byzantine Empire-related lists|Emp]] [[Category:Lists of royal consorts|Byzantine]]

page.title: List of countries by recoverable shale gas

revision.comment: Undid revision 820978937 by [[Special:Contributions/2606:A000:8187:8300:D90F:1B7:1237:BA3F|2606:A000:8187:8300:D90F:1B7:1237:BA3F]] ([[User talk:2606:A000:8187:8300:D90F:1B7:1237:BA3F|talk]]) not consistent with the EIA sources.
revision.text:
[[File:EIA World Shale Gas Map.png|thumb|450px|A map of 48 shale basins in 38 countries, based on US [[Energy Information Administration]] data, 2011.]] This is a '''list of countries by recoverable [[shale gas]]''' based on data collected by the [[Energy Information Administration]] agency of the [[United States Department of Energy]].{{cite web|title=Technically Recoverable Shale Oil and Shale Gas Resources: An Assessment of 137 Shale Formations in 41 Countries Outside the United States|url=http://www.eia.gov/analysis/studies/worldshalegas/|date=13 June 2013|work=Analysis and projections|publisher=United States Energy Information Administration}} Numbers for the estimated amount of recoverable shale gas resources are provided alongside numbers for [[List of countries by natural gas proven reserves|proven natural gas reserves]]. == Nations == {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right" !!!Country!!Estimated recoverable resources
{{nobold|(trillion cubic feet)}}!!Date of
Information |- | -||align="left"|[[World]] total|| 7,299 ||2013 |- | 1||align="left"|{{flag|China}}|| 1,115 ||2013 |- | 2||align="left"|{{flag|Argentina}}|| 802 ||2013 |- | 3||align="left"|{{flag|Algeria}}|| 707 ||2013 |- | 4||align="left"|{{flag|United States}}|| 665 ||2013 |- | 5||align="left"|{{flag|Canada}}|| 573 ||2013 |- | 6||align="left"|{{flag|Mexico}}|| 545 ||2013 |- | 7||align="left"|{{flag|Australia}}|| 437 ||2013 |- | 8||align="left"|{{flag|South Africa}}|| 390 ||2013 |- | 9||align="left"|{{flag|Russia}}|| 285 ||2013 |- | 10||align="left"|{{flag|Brazil}}|| 245 ||2013 |- | -||align="left"|Rest of the World|| 1,535||2013 |- |} ==See also== *[[Shale gas by country]] *[[Hydraulic fracturing by country]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Energy country lists}} {{Shale gas|technology=yes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Recoverable shale gas}} [[Category:Energy-related lists by country]] [[Category:Natural gas by country| List]] [[Category:Lists of countries]]

Retrieved January 17, 2006. |- | [[Havana]]||23.13 || '''{{CUB}}'''|| |- | [[Helsinki]]||60.17 || '''{{FIN}}'''|| |- | [[Honiara]]||−9.43 || '''{{SLB}}'''|| |- | [[Islamabad]]||33.72 || '''{{PAK}}'''|| |- | [[Jakarta]]||−6.2 || '''{{IDN}}'''|| |- | [[Jamestown, Saint Helena|Jamestown]]||−15.92 || {{flag|Saint Helena}}|| Part of the [[British Overseas Territory]] of [[Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha]] |- | [[Jerusalem]] (declared, de facto)||31.78 || '''{{ISR}}''' || [[Jerusalem Law]] states that "Jerusalem, complete and united, is the capital of Israel", and the city serves as the seat of the government, home to the president's residence, government offices, supreme court, and parliament. [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 478]] declared the Jerusalem Law "null and void" and called on member states to withdraw their diplomatic missions from Jerusalem. The United Nations and all member states maintain their embassies in other cities such as [[Tel Aviv]], [[Ramat Gan]], and [[Herzliya]], and do not recognise Jerusalem as the capital.See the [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/is.html CIA Factbook] and [https://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/israel.pdf Map of Israel] Many countries officially adhere to the proposal that Jerusalem have international status, as called for in the [[United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine|Partition Plan]] of 1947.{{cite book |last=Sharkansky |first=Ira |authorlink=Ira Sharkansky |title=Governing Jerusalem: Again on the world's agenda |page=23 |publisher=Wayne State University Press |year=1996 |isbn=0-8143-2592-0}} See [[Positions on Jerusalem]]. |- | [[Juba]]||4.85 || '''{{SSD}}'''|| |- | [[Kabul]]||34.53 || '''{{AFG}}'''|| |- | [[Kampala]]||0.3 || '''{{UGA}}'''|| |- | [[Kathmandu]]||27.7 || '''{{NPL}}'''|| |- | [[Khartoum]]||15.63 || '''{{SDN}}'''|| |- | [[Kigali]]||−1.93 || '''{{RWA}}'''|| |- | [[King Edward Point]]||−54.27 || {{SGS}}|| [[British Overseas Territory]] |- | [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]]||17.98 || '''{{JAM}}'''|| |- | [[Kingston, Norfolk Island|Kingston]]||−29.05 || {{NFK}}|| [[States and territories of Australia|External territory]] of [[Australia]] |- | [[Kingstown, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|Kingstown]]||13.15 || '''{{VCT}}'''|| |- | [[Kinshasa]]||−4.32 || '''{{COD}}'''|| |- | [[Kuala Lumpur]] (official, legislative and royal)

Claimed in whole by [[Georgia (country)|Republic of Georgia]] as the [[Autonomous Republic of Abkhazia]]. |- | [[Suva]]||−18.13 || '''{{FJI}}'''|| |- | [[Taipei]]||25.03 || '''{{TWN}}''' || Officially the Republic of China (ROC), it has been competing for recognition with the [[China|People's Republic of China]] (PRC) as the sole Chinese government since 1949. Taiwan controls the island of Taiwan and its associated islands, Quemoy, Matsu, the Pratas, and part of the [[Spratly Islands]]The sovereignty over the [[Spratly Islands]] is disputed by [[China]], [[Taiwan]], [[Vietnam]], the [[Philippines]] (part), [[Malaysia]] (part), and [[Brunei]] (part). Except Brunei, each of these countries occupies part of the islands (see [[List of territorial disputes]]). The territory of Taiwan is claimed in whole by China.In 1949, the Republic of China government led by the [[Kuomintang]] (KMT) lost the [[Chinese Civil War]] to the [[Communist Party of China]] (CPC) and set up a provisional capital in Taipei. The CPC established the People's Republic. As such, the [[Political status of Taiwan|political status]] of the ROC and the [[legal status of Taiwan]] (alongside the [[Free Area of the Republic of China|territories]] currently under ROC jurisdiction) are in dispute. In 1971, the [[United Nations]] gave the [[China and the United Nations|China seat]] to the PRC instead of the ROC: most states recognize the PRC to be the [[One-China policy|sole legitimate representative of all China]], and the UN classifies Taiwan as "[[Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China|Taiwan, Province of China]]". The ROC has ''de facto'' relations with most sovereign states. A significant political movement within Taiwan advocates [[Taiwan independence]]. The Republic of China participates in the [[World Health Organization]] and a number of non-UN international organizations such as the [[World Trade Organization]], [[International Olympic Committee]] and others under a variety of pseudonyms, most commonly [[Chinese Taipei]]. |- | [[Tallinn]]||59.43 || '''{{EST}}'''|| |- | [[Tarawa]]||1.43 || '''{{KIR}}'''|| |- | [[Tashkent]]||41.27 || '''{{UZB}}'''|| |- |[[Tbilisi]] (official)||41.72|| '''{{GEO}}'''|| |- | [[Tegucigalpa]]||14.1 || '''{{HND}}'''|| |- | [[Tehran]]||35.68 || '''{{IRN}}'''|| |- | [[Thimphu]]||27.47 || '''{{BTN}}'''|| |- | [[Tirana]]||41.32 || '''{{ALB}}'''|| |- | [[Tiraspol]]||46.85 || {{flag|Transnistria}}|| De facto independent state, not recognized by any UN-member, but by Abkhazia and South Ossetia. revision.text:
{{Infobox mountain | name = Mount Karthala | photo = Karthala volcano-Comoros.jpg | photo_caption = Karthala volcano crater in November 2006 | elevation_m = 2361 | elevation_ref = [http://www.peaklist.org/WWlists/ultras/africa.html Listed as "Le Kartala" on Peaklist.org] Retrieved 27 September 2011 | prominence_m = 2361 | prominence_ref = | map = Comoros | map_alt = | map_caption = | label_position = | listing = [[Ultra prominent peak|Ultra]]
[[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]] | location = [[Comoros]], [[Indian Ocean]] | coordinates = {{coord|11|45|24|S|43|21|42|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | topo = | type = [[Shield volcano]] (active) | age = | last_eruption = January 2007 | first_ascent = | easiest_route = |embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_offname = Le Karthala | designation1_date = 12 November 2006 | designation1_number = 1649{{Cite web|title=Le Karthala|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/1649|accessdate=25 April 2018}}}} }} '''Mount Karthala''' or '''Karthola''' ({{lang-ar|القرطالة}} ''Al Qirtālah'') is an active [[volcano]] and the highest point of the [[Comoros]] at {{Convert|2361|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} above sea level. It is the southernmost and larger of the two [[shield volcano]]es forming [[Grande Comore]] island, the largest [[island]] in the nation of Comoros. The Karthala volcano is very active, having erupted more than 20 times since the 19th century. Frequent eruptions have shaped the volcano’s 3 km by 4 km summit [[caldera]], but the island has largely escaped broad destruction. Eruptions on April 17, 2005 and May 29, 2006 ended a period of quiet. ==April 2005 eruption== [[Image:Karthala MODIS 20051125.jpg|left|thumb| Satellite image of Karthala volcano after its November 2005 eruption-ash completely obscures Grande Comore (outlined) as well as some other islands.]] The eruption, which carried a risk of [[lava flow]]s and deadly [[volcanic gas]], caused the evacuation of 30,000 residents. The crater was clearly changed by the April 2005 eruption. A grey field of ash surrounds the crater and the [[caldera]] itself seems larger and deeper. The [[crater lake]], which formed after Karthala's last eruption in 1991 and once dominated the caldera, is now gone completely. In its place were rough, dark grey rocks, possibly cooling lava or rubble from the collapsed crater. ==May 2006 activity== On May 29, [[Reuters]] reported that residents of [[Moroni, Comoros|Moroni]] could see lava at the top of the volcano.{{cite web |url=http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=scienceNews&storyID=2006-05-29T082108Z_01_L29707275_RTRUKOC_0_US-COMOROS-VOLCANO.xml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004140853/http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=scienceNews&storyID=2006-05-29T082108Z_01_L29707275_RTRUKOC_0_US-COMOROS-VOLCANO.xml |archivedate=2009-10-04 |df= }} Within a few days the volcanic activity subsided.[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/B590859.htm] ==Flora and fauna== The mountain is covered by moist evergreen forest up to about 1800 metres above sea-level. Higher up the vegetation consists of stunted trees and [[heathland]] where the giant heather ''[[Erica comorensis]]'' grows. Many of the species found on the mountain are unique to the Comoros and four [[bird]] species are found only on the slopes of Mount Karthala: [[Humblot's flycatcher]], [[Comoro white-eye]], [[Comoro drongo]] and [[Karthala scops owl]]. The mountain's forest is threatened by [[logging]] and the spread of agriculture. A [[nature reserve]] has been proposed to cover the mountain; it has not yet been created. ==References== {{Reflist}} * {{cite gvp|vnum=0303-01=|name=Karthala}} * {{cite gvp|vnum=0303-01=0303-01=&volpage=var#bgvn_3101|name=Karthala – Monthly Reports}} * {{WWF ecoregion|name=Comoros forests|id=at0105}} Downloaded 27/02/07. ==See also== * [[List of Ultras of Africa]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Karthala, Mount}} [[Category:Volcanoes of the Comoros]] [[Category:Mountains of the Comoros]] [[Category:Polygenetic shield volcanoes]] [[Category:Active volcanoes]] [[Category:Crater lakes]] [[Category:Ramsar sites in the Comoros]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]] {{Comoros-geo-stub}}

[[Image:Oba Lagos060602-N-8637R-006.jpg|thumb|Portrait of Oba [[Rilwan Akiolu]], 2006]] The '''Oba (''king'') of Lagos''' is the traditional, yet ceremonial, sovereign of [[Lagos]], a coastal Yoruba settlement that went on to become the largest city in [[Africa]] after first giving its name to [[Lagos State]], the acclaimed financial heart of contemporary [[Nigeria]]. The king has no political power, but is sought as a counsel or sponsor by Nigerian politicians who seek support from the various residents of Lagos. Among other ceremonial roles, the [[Oba (ruler)|Oba]] also plays a central part in the [[Eyo festival]] as well as indulging in tourism advertisements on behalf of the city, often stating, "you've gotta go to Lagos".
==History==
All Obas of Lagos trace their lineage to [[Ashipa]],<ref name="Mann-45">{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Kristin|title=Slavery and the Birth of an African City: Lagos, 1760-1900|publisher=Indiana University Press, 2007|isbn=9780253348845|page=45}}</ref> a war captain of the [[Oba of Benin]]. Ashipa was rewarded with title of ''Oloriogun''<ref name="JHK">{{cite book|last1=Herskovits Kopytoff|first1=Jean|title=A Preface to Modern Nigeria: The "Sierra Leoneans" in Yoruba, 1830 - 1890|publisher=University of Wisconsin Press|pages=64–65|accessdate=30 December 2016}}</ref> (or ''War leader'') and received the Oba of Benin's sanction to govern Lagos.<ref name=Folami>{{cite book|last1=Folami|first1=Takiu|title=A History of Lagos, Nigeria: The Shaping of an African City|publisher=Exposition Press|isbn=9780682497725|pages=22}}</ref> Some Benin accounts of history have the Ashipa as son or grandson of the Oba of Benin.<ref name="Smith">{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Robert|title=The Lagos Consulate, 1851-1861|publisher=University of California Press, 1979|isbn=9780520037465|page=4}}</ref> Other accounts note that Ashipa is a [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]] corruption of the [[Edo language|Benin]] name ''Aisika-hienbore'' (translated "we shall not desert this place").<ref name ="Cole">{{cite book|last1=Cole|first1=Patrick|title=Modern and Traditional Elites in the Politics of Lagos|publisher=Cambridge University Press, 1975|isbn=9780521204392|page=12}}</ref>
Ashipa received a sword and royal drum as symbols of his authority from the Oba of Benin on his mission to Lagos. Additionally, the [[Oba of Benin]] deployed a group of Benin officers charged with preserving Benin's interests in Lagos. These officers, led by [[Eletu Odibo]], were the initial members of the ''Akarigbere'' class of Lagos White Cap Chiefs.<ref name="JHK" />
Prior to the arrival of the British, the Oba of Benin had "the undisputed right to crown or confirm the individual whom the people of Lagos elect[ed] to be their King".<ref>{{cite book |author=Great Britain. Parliament. House of Commons |title=Accounts and Papers of the House of Commons|publisher=Great Britain. Parliament. House of Commons, 1852 |isbn= |page=97 |url=https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=aqVbAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA1-PA97&dq=akitoye+benin+undisputed+right&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=akitoye%20benin%20undisputed%20right&f=false |accessdate=8 September 2017 }}</ref>
The defeat of Oba [[Kosoko]] by British forces on December 28, 1851, in what is now known as the [[Bombardment of Lagos]] or [[Reduction of Lagos]], or locally as Ogun Ahoyaya or Ogun Agidingbi (after boiling cannons), put an end to Lagos' s former allegiance to the Oba of Benin.<ref>{{cite book| title=Sociocultural Dimensions of Nigerian Pidgin Usage (Western NigerDelta of Nigeria| author=Oloruntoba, C.I.| url=https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=s1ceAQAAMAAJ&dq=John+Beecroft++%22Oba+of+Benin%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=protectorate++%22Oba+of+Benin%22| year=1992| publisher=Indiana University| accessdate =26 July 2017}}</ref>
Kosoko was therefore the last Oba of Lagos to remit annual tributes from the people of Lagos to the Oba of Benin. Oba [[Akitoye]], who was re-installed to the throne by the British, "seized the opportunity of his restoration under British protection to repudiate his former allegiance" to Benin and rebuffed subsequent tribute requests from the Oba of Benin.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ryder|first1=Alan Frederick Charles|title=Benin and the Europeans: 1485-1897|publisher=Front Cover Alan Frederick Charles Ryder Humanities Press, 1969 - Benin|pages=241–242|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Robert|title=The Lagos Consulate, 1851-1861|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=0333240545|pages=6,27,90,102}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ryder|first1=Alan Frederick Charles|title=Benin and the Europeans: 1485-1897|publisher=Humanities Press, 1969 - Benin|pages=241–242|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref>
Previous rulers of Lagos have used the titles of [[Ologun Kutere|Ologun]] (derived from Oloriogun), [[Eshugbayi Eleko|Eleko]] and, most recently, Oba of Lagos.<ref>{{cite book| title=Kingdoms of the Yoruba| author=Robert Sydney Smith| url=https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=ric6OhxbCS0C&pg=PA74&dq=ashipa+oloriogun&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=ashipa%20oloriogun&f=false| publisher=Univ of Wisconsin Press 1969| accessdate =30 July 2017}}</ref>
The current Oba of Lagos, His Highness Oba [[Rilwan Akiolu]], has served in the position since May 2003.
==The Royal Seat== The official residence of the king, since 1630, is [[Iga Idunganran]], a castle constructed by the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] over the course of close to a century. It is today a very popular tourist site.
==List of Obas of Lagos== * [[Ashipa]] (c1682-1716)<ref>{{cite book|author=Aimiuwu, O.E.I.|title=Ashipa: the first Oba of Lagos|publisher=Nigeria Magazine, Issues 100-104, Government of Nigeria 1969|pages=624–627|url= http://www.africabib.org/rec.php?RID=183298764|accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=MCHSd62Tse8C |page=29 }} |title=Slavery and the Birth of an African City |work= |page=29 }}</ref> *[[Ado (Lagos Oba)|Ado]] (1716–1755) (son of [[Ashipa]]/Esikpa)<ref name="plainsail">{{cite web|url=http://www.eraffoundation.org/erelukuti.php|title=Erelu Abiola Docemo Foundation|author=Plainsail|work=eraffoundation.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://members.iinet.net.au/~royalty/states/nigeria/lagos.html|title=LAGOS|work=iinet.net.au}}</ref> * [[Gabaro]] (1755–1760)<ref name="adewunmielegbede">{{cite web|url=http://www.kingdomsofnigeria.com/kings/view_pastking.php?name=Oba%20of%20lagos|title=Kingdoms of Nigeria, The Nigerian Database of Rulers, Kings, Kingdoms, Political and Traditional Leaders|author=Adewunmi Elegbede|work=kingdomsofnigeria.com}}</ref> * [[Akinsemoyin]] (''c''.1760-1775) <ref name="google.com.br">{{cite book |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=MCHSd62Tse8C |page=46 }} |title=Slavery and the Birth of an African City |work= |page=46 }}</ref> * [[Eletu Kekere]] (c1775 - 1780) * [[Ologun Kutere]] (also ''Ologunkutere / Ologunkuture'') (1780-1801)<ref name="google.com.br" /> or until 1803 <ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.br/books?id=CBDWuJb9VI8C&pg=PA95&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Ajan&f=false|title=Slavery in Africa and the Caribbean: A History of Enslavement and Identity Since the 18th Century|last=Ojo|first=Olatunji|last2=Hunt|first2=Nadine|date=2012-09-15|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9781780761152|language=en}}</ref> * Interregnum between Ologun Kutere and Adele (c 1805 - c1810/11) <ref name="Mann-45" /> * [[Adele Ajosun]] (1811-1821) <ref name="Mann-45" /> * [[Osinlokun|Oṣinlokun Ajan]] (''Oshinlokun, Eshinlokun'') (1821–1829)<ref name="google.com.br" /><ref name=":0" /> * [[Idewu Ojulari]] (1829–1832)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> or until 1835 <ref name="google.com.br" /> * [[Adele Ajosun]] (second term) (1835-1837) <ref name="Mann-45" /> * [[Oluwole]] (1837-1841)<ref name="adewunmielegbede"/><ref name=":0" /><ref name="google.com.br3">{{cite book |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=MCHSd62Tse8C |page=46 }} |title=Slavery and the Birth of an African City |work= }}</ref> * [[Akitoye]] (1841-1845)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /><ref name="google.com.br3" /><ref name="google.com.br1">{{cite book|url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=CBDWuJb9VI8C |page=95 }}|title=Slavery in Africa and the Caribbean|work=|page=95}}</ref> * [[Kosoko]] (1845–1851)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /><ref name="google.com.br" /><ref name="google.com.br1" /> * [[Akitoye]] (second term) (1851-1853)<ref name="adewunmielegbede"/> * [[Dosunmu]] (1853–1885)<ref name="adewunmielegbede"/><ref name="google.com.br3"/> * [[Oyekan I]] (1885–1900)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> * [[Eshugbayi Eleko]] (1901-1925)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> * [[Ibikunle Akitoye]] (1925–1928)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> * [[Sanusi Olusi]] (1928–1931)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> * [[Eshugbayi Eleko]] (second term) (1931-1932)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> * [[Falolu Dosunmu]] (1932–1949)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> * [[Adeniji Adele]] (1949–1964)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> * [[Adeyinka Oyekan|Adeyinka Oyekan II]] (1965–2003)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" /> * [[Rilwan Akiolu]] (2003–present)<ref name="adewunmielegbede" />

The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Bangladesh:
'''[[Bangladesh]]''' – [[List of sovereign states|sovereign country]] located in South Asia.<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=2 July 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bg.html|title=Bangladesh|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=United States [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=23 July 2009}}</ref> It is bordered by [[India]] on all sides except for a small border with [[Burma]] to the far southeast and by the [[Bay of Bengal]] to the south. Together with the Indian state of [[West Bengal]], it makes up the ethno-linguistic region of [[Bengal]]. The name ''Bangladesh'' means "The land of Bengal" in the official [[Bengali language]]. Bangladesh became an independent nation in 1971 after a struggle for independence from Pakistan led by [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]] and [[Ziaur Rahman|Major Ziaur Rahman]]. Bangladesh is the eight-most populous country and the fifth most populous democracy in the world.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}

===== Subdistricts of Bangladesh =====
[[Upazilas of Bangladesh]] The districts are subdivided into 493 sub-districts, or [[Upazilas of Bangladesh|upazila]].
===== Cities of Bangladesh ===== * Major cities of Bangladesh ** [[Dhaka]] – capital city and the political, economic and cultural heart of Bangladesh. Dhaka is the most populous city in Bangladesh and the tenth-largest city in the world, with a population of over 15 million inhabitants. ** [[Chittagong]] – second most populous city and main seaport of Bangladesh. It is a major commercial, financial and industrial hub. Located on the Karnaphuli River, it is the administrative seat of Chittagong District and Chittagong Division (the largest division of Bangladesh). The metropolitan area has a population of 4 million residents. ** [[Khulna]] – third-largest city in Bangladesh, with a population of more than 1.4 million people. Khulna is also the third largest economic centre in Bangladesh. The major sectors are jute, chemicals, fish and seafood packaging, food processing, sugar mills, power generation and shipbuilding. ** [[Rajshahi]] – Rajshahi is a prominent commercial hub and industrial centre of North Bengal. For its venerable silk industry, it is nicknamed "Silk City". It has a population of more than 800,000. ** [[Barisal]] – city in southern Bangladesh, rice and other crops producing centre of Bangladesh. Fish is also plentiful because Barisal stands on the Kirtankhola River and is surrounded by it. A Bengali saying states, ''Dhan, nadi, khal ai tine Barisal'', which translates to "paddy, river and canal are the three things that make Barisal". It is a fast growing city, with nearly 0.38 million people and a divisional headquarters, university, medical college, engineering college, cadet college, some pharmaceutical industries, and textile industries. The city is sometimes called the "[[List of places called Venice of the East|Venice of the East]]" or the "Venice of Bengal".<ref>[http://thedailystar.net/suppliments/2006/15thanniv/ourcities/ourcities15.htm Thedailystar.net]</ref> ** [[Sylhet]] – city with a population of over 500,000 people that lies on the banks of Surma River in north-east Bangladesh. It is surrounded by tea estates, sub-tropical hills, rain forests and river valleys; the region is one of the leading tourist destinations in the country. ** [[Comilla]] – city in eastern Bangladesh, located along the Dhaka-Chittagong Highway, 97 kilometres from the capital city, Dhaka, which can also be reached by railway. Comilla is second-largest city of eastern Bangladesh after Chittagong and is one of the three oldest cities in Bangladesh. ** [[Rangpur City]] – 5th-largest city in Bangladesh, located in its north western part. Agricultural products such as rice, jute (called the golden fibre of Bangladesh), wheat, tobacco, and potato are the major driving power of the economy here. ** [[Narayanganj]] – city in central Bangladesh, located in the Narayanganj District, near the capital city of Dhaka. The city is on the bank of the Shitalakshya River and has a population of 220,000. The river port of Narayanganj is one of the oldest in Bangladesh. It is also a centre of business and industry, especially the jute trade and processing plants, and of the textile sector of the country. ** [[Gazipur City]] – city in central Bangladesh with a population of over 1.1 million. ** '''[[List of City Corporations of Bangladesh|more cities]]...''' * [[List of cities and towns in Bangladesh]]

== History of Bangladesh ==
[[History of Bangladesh]] * [[History of Bangladesh]] * [[Timeline of Bangladeshi history]] * [[History of Bengal]] – geographical and ethno-linguistic region in South Asia. was politically divided in the 1947 Partition of Bengal based on religion: predominantly Hindu West Bengal became a province (now a state) of India, and predominantly Muslim East Bengal (now Bangladesh) became a province of Pakistan.
